awd_titl_txt: Workshop/Collaborative Research: NSF Proposal Writing Workshop at 46th SME NAMRC and ASME MSEC 2018; Texas A&M University; College Station, Texas; June 18, 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funds to conduct a National Science Foundation (NSF) proposal-writing workshop concurrent with the 46th Society of Manufacturing Engineers North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2018). The workshop will be held at Texas A&M University on Monday, June 18, 2018, building on the success of previous similar workshops held at the three previous NAMRC/MSEC conferences. The aim of the workshop is to aid future NSF proposal submitters in communicating clear research objectives and improving proposal quality. Participants will learn guidelines for writing a quality NSF proposal with an emphasis on the research objective. Interactions during the workshop will help build meaningful collaborations. This will positively affect the attendees' academic career and, subsequently, will help develop the nation's human resources. Additionally, when proposals are well written, the reviews tend to be more consistent and NSF panel meetings are more efficient. 

Major activities of the workshop include: presentations by NSF program directors, breakout sessions to discuss example research objectives, a group question/answer period, and a conclusions session. Professors and graduate students from across the US will be invited to attend the workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the proposed proposal-writing workshop was to help young faculty to write more competitive research proposals. The workshop was held concurrently with the 46 SME North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the 2018 ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2018). The workshop was held at Texas A&M University, College Station, TX on June 18, 2018, building on the success of previous similar workshops held at the three previous NAMRC/MSEC conferences. The workshop organizers were ZJ Pei (Texas A&M University), George Hazelrigg (George Mason University) and Tony Schmitz (University of Tennessee, Knoxville).

A goal of the workshop was to improve the overall quality of proposals submitted to the National Science Foundation?s research programs, particularly in the area of manufacturing research and specifically for proposals that will be submitted to the Advanced Manufacturing cluster. Many young faculty members are in the position of seeking research funding in support of research conducted by them and their students. However, they have received little or no formal training in the art of research proposal writing, and their proposals fail to be competitive. It has been observed that a particular weakness lies in their inability to adequately formulate and express their research objectives and to create a coherent research plan designed specifically to accomplish their stated objectives. This workshop addressed these weaknesses.

The workshop included a working lunch with an introductory talk that reviewed NSF statistical data that showed the benefits of learning effective proposal writing; a writing exercise where attendees were presented with a propeller toy and asked to write instructions for its assembly and use with an emphasis on completeness and clarity; a lectures that defined research and discussed what distinguishes research from development; a writing exercise where attendees wrote research summaries; a group activity to review the summaries and identify strengths and weaknesses with a focus on the research objectives; and a presentation on ethical and responsible conduct of research emphasizing the need for grantees to comply with applicable Federal regulations and to establish and maintain an environment of high ethical standards.

Intellectual Merit: The workshop included 55 attendees. Activities included presentations by on effective proposal writing, a group writing exercise, individual activities to practice defining a research objective, a group activity to discuss example research summaries, and a question/answer period with NSF personnel.

Broader Impacts: Professors and graduate students from both the U.S. and other countries attended the workshop. They learned guidelines for writing a quality research objective. Interactions during the workshop with colleagues helped foster meaningful collaborations. The relationships developed during the workshop will positively affect the attendees? academic careers and, subsequently, will help develop the nation?s human resources. Additionally, by improving the participants? proposals, the panel reviews will be more consistent. This will help in making the NSF panel review meetings run more smoothly.
